Also some tips and tricks with generative AI

title: Using GitHub Copilot with Our Libraries
content:
#

> Original written: 03/28/2025

GitHub Copilot is a wonderful tool that now allows us to automatically attach
markdown files as context for code generation, code review, and test generation.
Additionally, Copilot offers a powerful feature called reusable prompts, which
can help us create code with predefined instructions.

When experimenting with our libraries, we wanted to take advantage of these
features. First, we modified our .vscode settings to point to our prompts and
code generation files. You can find more information on how to do this in this
link.

Next, we started creating the instructions. For instance, in the file
.github/copilot-instructions.md, we specified that we use React 19, a monorepo
setup, and included health advice and words of encouragement—because empathy
matters.

Now, GitHub Copilot Chat provides answers while keeping those files in context
with our custom instructions.


The Prompt File#

To create components using one of our packages, we needed to reference the code
of that package. GitHub Copilot documentation suggests doing this in the form of
markdown links. Since we have the code in the same monorepo, we can reference it
directly. However, if you are using our libraries without direct access to the
source code in the same repository, how can this be solved?

You can reference the code in your node_modules folder, including the
corresponding typings. While the JavaScript code is minified and harder for
GitHub Copilot to use, the typings are still accessible.

Here’s an example of how to do this:



Make sure to adjust the paths relative to the location of your prompt file.


Final Words#

Yes, we should document the API and typings in our libraries to further enhance
AI code generation. Nevertheless, this example can be expanded to other
scenarios and libraries beyond our own.

title: Component react creators
content:
#


What does it do?#

These utilities are actually react component factories for what some libraries
like MUI and Mantine know as Polymorphic Components and also to create
components that extract some props and use them to resolve the className. There
is a reason we are creating this; we have some ideas in mind following the
article we published in medium to create some optimizations in build/compile
time.

In short, this means you can create a Button that can render not only as a
button but as any other React ElementType.

Also you are going to be able to create a className resolver function that
extracts from your props what info is needed to create a className according to,
for instance, some variants of your component, and separate them from the real
props of the component.

I almost forgot to mention that it is typesafe, so your IDE is going to
autocomplete the needed props.

> ⚠️ WARNING: This library is only compatible with React 19. It will not work
> with earlier versions of React due to dependency on new features and APIs
> introduced in React 19.


Installation#


Usage#


Creating a styled component#

This is a factory of a polymorphic component that also accepts variant props for
your custom className resolver



The extractStyleProps is a needed function to separate what props are real props
of your component (componentOwnProps) and what props are going to be used to
resolve the className (styleProps).

The classNameResolver will only get what you defined in extractStyleProps as
styleProps and you may use that to form your final className to get the correct
styles.

Sometimes you would want not to modify the className but the style prop, this is
to apply change control via css vars; for those cases we provide a styleResolver
function.





In any case, you can use the Button component like this:




Example with tailwindVariants and Rambda#



Then you can use your shiny button like this



Why would I want a button that is a link? Well, because sometimes you need the
styles of a button in an anchor tag.


Creating a only polymorphic component#

But if you do not want to create a custom className resolver and only need a
polymorphic component you can use createReactMetaComponent


Creating a component that extracts some props to create the className#

But this time it is not a polymorphic component, you can use
createComponentWithStyleProps and the component is not going to have an as prop.



This component is always going to be a button.


Final words#

Obviously you may use directly a classname resolver of your liking directly in
any component directly in the code like this (suppose we were using
tailwindVariants):



And it is really good, but we wanted to give some structure to react components
to make them have all your variants by props.

If you read the article about our ideas that came from our adventures in the
place where we study, you may know we are planning on using a compiler to make
some optimizations at build time.

And since react is something that is going to be in our projects, we wanted to
make the first step in this direction.

title: Introduction
content:
#

We are creating several libraries to help us build design systems, especially
for React.js. It is going to be a long journey ahead of us.

This idea was born during a university project where we were challenged to meet
several constraints because we asked for a more demanding task.

We know there are many excellent tools out there that are evolving rapidly,
offering great developer experience (DX), decent performance, and portability.
However, they did not fully meet 100% of the requirements we were tasked with,
such as:

 * Short build times
 * No runtime overhead
 * 90% CSS coverage
 * Compatibility with React Server Components (RSC) and runtime style
   information (SSR)
 * Good JSX developer experience


Projects That Inspire Us#

While researching tools to assist with our project, we discovered some amazing
libraries that inspired us or even became the foundation of our tools. We are
deeply grateful to the open-source community for their incredible work:

 * Radix
 * Tamagui
 * Stitches
 * Mantine
 * UnoCSS
 * Tailwind
 * Tailwind Variants


Some Context...#

For example, we wanted to use a CSS variant generator because you often don't
know what variants you'll need at compile time. All the classes representing
possible states of that variant were generated, but the CSS coverage was not
acceptable to our mentors.

Then we discovered Tamagui, which was wonderful because it optimized JSX by
extracting variants and creating a CSS file with only the classes that were
used. We love Tamagui.

However, we needed to use the components as RSC, and the styles were not known
ahead of time for those RSC components since we were fetching that information
from a remote data source (SSR).

The heuristics for compiling a component were lost because we didn't know which
variant value to apply until runtime.

This is why we are building tools to help us create, with luck, a complete
framework that addresses all the constraints we are facing.

In this context, we do not aspire to replace these very powerful libraries. We
are simply experimenting with some ideas.


The Road Ahead#

Currently, we are building a library of React component creators and, around
that, a Tailwind wrapper using Tailwind Variants (we love Tailwind Variants).

To address the missing responsive variants, we are creating a Babel loader and a
Vite plugin to generate all the responsive variants at compile time.

Next, we plan to create an SWC plugin to extract only the necessary classes from
JSX syntax and transform them into optimized components with only the required
Tailwind classes.

The component creator will assist us in development mode while we learn enough
Rust to create the plugin.

For RSC components with runtime data sources, we aim to create a set of Next.js
utilities to register the required classes during SSG mode. These utilities will
use the resolved values to generate only the necessary classes in the CSS file
and inline the critical CSS.

For client components, the approach is slightly different. We are exploring ways
to extract the classes passed to the client component from the server component,
possibly using a proxy.

These approaches will require a strong set of rules and conventions, which we
need to effectively communicate through warnings and linter rules.

As you can see, there is a lot of work to do, and we are just getting started.


What We Have So Far#

We have several packages, but the three most useful are:

@dyesthetics-lab/react-component-creators This is our base library for creating
polymorphic components with styles and variants.

 * @dyesthetics-lab/react-tv-variants-creators A wrapper around Tailwind
   Variants and @dyesthetics-lab/react-component-creators to create responsive
   variants. Note: This does not work as a standalone library.

 * @dyesthetics-lab/tailwind-manifest-creators To effectively create responsive
   variants, we need to generate a manifest with all the responsive variants so
   TailwindCSS can read it and generate the required CSS. This module includes
   loaders and plugins to help with this process. (We are also planning to offer
   a codegen CLI as an alternative to this package.)

You can test the following libraries:

 * @dyesthetics-lab/react-component-creators
 * @dyesthetics-lab/react-tv-variants-creators
 * @dyesthetics-lab/tailwind-utils
 * @dyesthetics-lab/tailwind-manifest-creators
 * @dyesthetics-lab/tailwind-utils


Can I Help Out?#

Of course! We are looking for contributors to help us with the project. We want
to learn, but we are currently very busy with university, so please be patient
if we don't respond immediately. Nevertheless, any PR from a fork will be
reviewed within the same week it is submitted.


Final Words#

We are here to learn and greatly appreciate any feedback you can provide.

Additionally, we have an article that inspired this project. We created the
libraries shortly after the article was published.

title: Tailwind Manifest Creators
content:
#


Introduction#

The @dyesthetics-lab/tailwind-manifest-creators package creates manifest files
containing all Tailwind CSS class variants used in your project. A manifest file
is a collection of all the Tailwind classes that your application might use,
which are extracted from your configuration files. This manifest enables
Tailwind to efficiently process only the classes your application actually
needs, improving build performance and reducing CSS bundle size.

WARNING

This package is specifically designed to work with Tailwind CSS v4, which
introduced the @source directive for improved class extraction.


Installation#


Usage#


Manifest Creator#

The package exports a createManifest function that generates a manifest file
containing all Tailwind class variants that match a specified glob pattern.

To implement this in your build process, create a pre-build script file (e.g.,
pre-build.ts):



The globPath parameter specifies which files to scan for Tailwind class
definitions. In this example, we're searching for all files with the
.tailwindConfig.json extension.


Configuration Files#

Your project should contain one or more configuration files matching the
specified glob pattern. These files define the Tailwind variants your components
use.

Example tailwindConfig.json:



INFO

Note that the responsiveVariants option in your configuration controls whether
responsive variants are generated. When set to true, the manifest will include
responsive variants (like sm:, md:, lg:) for your classes. The tool does not
automatically create responsive variants - it generates them based on your
configuration.


Integrating with Your Build Process#

Configure the pre-build script in your package.json:



When you run your build process, the pre-build script will execute first,
creating a global.tailwind.manifest file in node_modules/.tailwind-manifests/.
This manifest will contain all Tailwind classes found in your configuration
files, including responsive variants if specified.

css entry point:
